headline: Homemade Crispy Seasoned French Fries
description: This clever homemade fries recipe uses a rich batter seasoned with garlic and paprika to create super crispy French fries the whole family will love.

video.description: These fries stay crispy even reheated in the microwave!
video.name: Homemade Crispy Seasoned French Fries

name: Homemade Crispy Seasoned French Fries

recipeInstructions.text: Slice potatoes into French fries and place them into a large bowl of cold water to prevent them from turning brown.
Heat oil in a heavy saucepan or large skillet to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
While the oil is heating, sift flour, garlic salt, onion salt, paprika, and salt into a large bowl. Gradually stir in enough water to make a slightly thick batter that can be drizzled from a spoon.
Drain fries and pat dry; dip into the batter one at a time.
Place fries in hot oil and prevent them from clumping together. Fry until golden brown and crispy on all sides, about 7 to 10 minutes.
Drain fries on a paper towel-lined plate.

review.reviewBody: these are awesome taste like five guys burger and fries only the thing is they clump but still awesome
ok
my son made them they were delesios

Omg omg these are to die for! I followed the instructions plus the advice in the comments. Added a lot more salt and parboiled the potatoes for a few minutes. As I only had a small pot I had to fry in several stages leaving the first batches soggy so I double fried them. Perfect!!!
great
i love it üòª üòç ü•∞
She was right about the batter sticking. What a mess. Taste was okay.
Really good! I added some cayenne Pepper to it as well.
It was nice, crispy, and tender

These were really good. The only drawback would be is you need to be prepared to take a long time to cook these because you literally have to cook them like 1 at a time or they clump badly. 20 minutes we only had about 10 french fries which unfortunately our burgers were done so then we just gave up & let them clump. We just served on 1 plate & let everyone break up clumps. I did marinate my slices potatoes in worscterschire, Greek seasoning & all season salt then removed the fries and put them in freezer bags to chill for a few hours before fry time. They were crispy h delicious!!
Nice and crispy! Will do again.
These fries were so VERY AWESOME!!!!

Woohoooo!! I am the french fry hero of my family! This recipe solves the soggy homemade fry problem. My family said these were probably the best fries they have ever had. Fries stay crispy for a long time and also retain heat very well. Put them in an oven at low temp (~170 deg) and they are perfect for at least an hour. Seasoning is just right. You can play with the spices to get bolder flavors but the basic recipe is spot on. One tip: keep a small amount of the dry mix to add in near the end. The batter tends to get runny from the water on the fries and a little dry mix will thicken it some. It is a little more work than just homemade fries, but very much worth it.

They were super greasy and took forever and honestly had no flavor even after using almost all the salt in the house. And then when you salted them after frying they seemed too salty. Such a waste. I just left most my fries plain and fried them, then a little salt and pepper, those were wonderful. I would not waste your time. I am super bummed because allrecipes.com is my go to recipe site. They should remove this one.

I made the recipe just like it said but used my fryer. I dropped the fries in one at a time but then stirred around after a few seconds and they didn‚Äôt stick together. It‚Äôs messy and takes a while but they are delicious!! I also used 1 cup of beer and a little water.
Yum! It takes quite a bit more water to get to proper consistency, just a heads up
Followed as written. I am in love with this recipe and it is now my go to fry recipe!

This was a very easy recipe. I started out dipping the fries in the batter, then had the idea to use the leftover batter for a crispy chicken patty in a sandwich. Everything turned out tasting very good (both fries & chicken patty) and no batter was wasted.
The best FF I‚Äôve had in a long time. If not the beat ever!!
I really enjoyed this recipe. I was looking for more of Cajun( Popeye's) flavor, but with some sea-salt to top it off. They tasted amazing. Thank you..

So I‚Äôve never made Fries before so I‚Äôm not knocking this recipe . The batter was just to thick I wish I would‚Äôve made it thinner. I used half beer half water .. still added extra water. Just to thick so it tasted like flour. My husband liked. them though (:
Excellent recipe, my family loved it. Will definitely make it again
Easy and delicious.
These are excellent!! No matter how many I cook my family eats them ALL!!
This will give you crispy fries. You can spice it to your liking. I used garlic powder instead of salt. Cayenne pepper would be a nice addition if you like spicy fries.

Came out great.... did add some Cajun seasoning about 1 tsp. Made some grilled chicken and veggies ( green beans , carrots and corn). My boys ate it up along side some choices of dipping sauces like BBQ, ketchup and ranch.

OK so I tried this and the seasoning batter just slipped right off the potatoes as they cooked. Needless to say mine look nothing like the pictures lol I' super bummed out about it. I'm letting them cook longer to at least get crunchy well-cooked fries.

Made as recipe suggested except added cayenne and seasoned salt, as well as more water to batter. They were amazing! My husband was blown away! Took some to my neighbors and they proclaimed me "The best French Fry maker in the Land!"
The garlic and onion taste was too overpowering. I‚Äôll use less next time or just use different seasonings.

I wanted to make lunch for my entire family entirely by myself, and not my mom. I wanted to make Spaghetti and Fries, so I‚Äôve used a recipe for fries that I used before, and they still turned out good! (P.S. For the spices of the fries, I only used Old Bay, cuz it‚Äôs a Maryland classic ;P)

These are delicious. I used shortening instead of oil. (No, shortening no longer contains trans fats.)
Next time I am adding a little cayene to the batter, but they were good just as written.
It was perfect and my duaghter loved them too .. its so easy too
Love it! I love all my food e tea seasoned so I added extra (total seasoning) and it turned out great!
Absolutely wonderful recipe! Easy to follow and make, the fries taste great! The whole family loved them! Will definitely make this again!
These fries are delicious and easy! I was very pleasantly surprised.
It was a lot of work and took a while, but it was definitely worth it! The batter can easily be tailored to your own tastes.

These were really crunchy but needed a little more flavor. Next time I‚Äôll try to add more spices and use half as much flour. I ended up with a lot of wasted floor. Overall, really good and is very similar to a beer battered taco coating!

My son and I loved these. My husband, not so much. He said the batter made the fries more like a "potato tempura". He likes naked french fries. The fries were very crisp and the flavor of the batter was great. No need to season afterward. I placed the fries on a cookie rack over a pan to catch dripping oil. Will need more than the 1/2 cup of water to get the batter to the right consistency. Like others have said, dry the potatoes well before you put them in the batter. Great recipe!
Batter needed to be thined out and fries needed to be cut smaller ( had a hard time getting them cook all the way) super bland seasoning, needs way more flavor. Added salt and pepper after cooking

Made recipe as stated. It was just as crispy as tasty as the recipe stated it would be. I almost, that's ALMOST felt guilty about eating these. Next time, i'll play with the seasonings and experiment, but these were great as is.
It's yummy. My 13 year old daughter was able to make it. She likes to help with dinner and in the kitchen, except cleaning lol.
I will never go back to store fries again. I cooked them til they were golden on the outside but not done completely. I froze them on a cookie sheet & bagged & froze them til needed
Amazing taste and FAST to make!
was easy and lived up to expectstion. added a little seasoning salt once out the oil.

What a great concept! I didn't have flour so I substituted with pancake mix and added the seasonings to taste. I soaked the potatoes for aesthetic purposes and then poured the batter on the fries after draining the water. I let them sit in the batter and put a few fries in the oil at a time. They did stick together a bit but not too much. I broke them apart gently with a fork. My daughters ate all of them without ketchup, which they never do with fries. They always make fry sauce, but not with these! I was very pleasantly surprised and will definitely make these again!
Same recipe and turned out great tasty.
Went by recipe except added more water for a thinner consistency and they were scrumptious!
I didn't measure the seasoning I just added what looked good. They turned out amazing! They turned out very crispy and they satisfied my pregnancy craving for fast food frenchfries.

I liked the tip about making a thinner batter in a plastic container with a lid for shaking and using tongs, that was helpful. I altered the spices using A1 dry rub seasoning, onion powder, garlic powder, paprika, ground dry mustard, salt and pepper. I recommend pulling out a handful or two of potatoes and letting the water drain off for a couple minutes before battering them, and put them in one at a time with the tongs. They didn't even need ketchup, they were so good. I had enough cut potatoes for a large mixing bowl, rinsed them several times before proceeding further and still had a little batter left over.
Delicious and way better than fries at fast food places! Quality fries that are restaurant level. I added basil and cayenne pepper to spice it up, but other than more spices, this works great!

These were an UTTER DISASTER! First, WAY too much paprika. I just sprinkled it over the batter. I used granulated garlic powder and onion powder without the salt, then added kosher salt, cayenne, black pepper and parsley.

I followed the video to the letter, but the fries stuck to the bottom of the fryer like glue. The end result was a hard, semi- gelatinous mess with under-cooked potatoes. I drained them, placed them on a sheet pan and baked them, then ate them as home fries. Next time, I will just cut fresh potatoes as shown, soak them in SALT water then just fry them, dry them, then immediately place in a paper sack with the seasoning I used mentioned above and shake. DONE. No mess.

Glad other people liked this recipe but my family did not like it. Potatoes were not meant to be breaded. The best way we've learned to make crispy fries is very simple. You par-cook the potatoes either in oil until they are about 3/4 done and remove them to drain the oil but are not browned. Alternatively, you can microwave the potato until it's about 3/4 cooked before cutting into fries. Then you put them into 350 degree oil until browned and crispy. Use seasoned salt or sea salt immediately after removing the fries from the oil before they drain the cooking oil completely. Works perfectly every time.
In
I like it but am still tinkering with it to suit my taste. It's good as the recipes goes but I am experimenting to make it just a little better if possible.

Wondeeeeeeeerful! Everybody loved it!! They really couldn't have enough! My father called it addictive. The only thing I recommend is to follow the recepie and put the potatos one by one. I tried (with my laziness) to put it all in the batter and the potatos started to release its water, so I had to add a little more flour and returned to the amazing batter from before! Thank you for introducing this greatness in my life haha 
God bless
Good flavor but batter had a problem sticking to the fries. Next time I'm going to do the old wet, dry, wet method.

Instead of regular potatoes i used sweet potatoes! these turned out amazing! my brother normally doesn't like sweet potatoes but he loved these fries!! i will definitely be trying these again but with normal potatoes next time! i recommend using sweet potatoes though!!
Delicious! Thanks so much! I am impatient too so I put all of the fries into coat and then cooked in batches. Great recipe!
So delicious, I love it!

These tasted great and were definitely crispy, however the cook time is definitely inaccurate and you will need quite a bit more than the recommended amount of water. Count on 8-10 minutes of cook time per batch. We cut the recipe in half and needed to cook the potatoes in three batches which took us about half an hour.

Solid recipe! I didn't use a sifter because i didn't have one and i kept the potato skins on because i personally really like them, we will definitely make again.. Not to mention i think this batter could work well with a lot of other things.
Kids and I lo bed this recipe. Will definitely make again.

I made this exactly as the recipe read and my wife and kids couldn't get enough. I couldn't make them fast enough. They were even delicious reheated the next day which is unheard of with most French fries.
Excellent crispy fries. I did increases the amount of spices & the amount of water to a pancake batter consistency. I used the batter for chicken strips too. *****

I've made these a few times already and LOVE them . Excellent recipe -- and my husband thinks so too, which is all that matters anyway, amiright?? I followed the recipe as is, only I added a little salt on the fries just after they came out of the oil. Delish.

Great recipe but absolutely NOT 25 minutes. I signed up just to comment and let others know this is quite a process. Im sure if I had a deep fryer it be less time-consuming. Other than that, pretty good!
Amazing! I did pre-fry the fries before battering. These were a hit!
Delicious! Skipped the paprika. Will make again!

Oh yes!! I LOVE a crispy fry and this recipe did the trick! I added enough water to make the batter the consistency of pancake batter. I put the fries in the oil one at a time as instructed. I still had to break them apart after they were frying for a few minutes. I probably cooked them longer than the recommended time, but I like my fries extra crispy. This is truly a keeper!!
best fries ever boyfriend and inlaws loved them!

I didn't have the garlic and onion salt so I used a minced clove of garlic and some seasoning salt.

I don't know if I used too much water but the oil was foaming at the top and the fries kept sticking to the bottom of the pan.

It seemed to take a long time and in the meantime I kept the fries in a foil packet inside the oven.

The fries were crispy but it was nothing to write home about. It was slightly better than my usual batch but not as good as I hoped, according to all the descriptions and reviews.

Will be looking for another recipe. Cheers.

Great recipe! I had leftover batter, so I coated some onion rings and fried them after the potatoes. I think they were even better than the french fries. Seriously, try this with onions and you will be amazed.
I loved these! I just added 1 tsp of french fry seasoning. That's the only extra!
I will totally make this again. The fries were finally crispy....perfect! Loved gem!!
YUM! I made these and I loved it! I would of never thought to make a homemade batter like this for Fries! It turned out great! cripsy, tastey and yummyyyy

Loved this! Really quick and easy to make. The fries came out so crispy and had a great crunch almost like a onion ring kinda crunch. Once I took them out of the oil I seasoned them right away with salt so it sticks to the fries, if you add it afterwards it won't stick . I will make this again for sure! So much cheaper then buying them already made.
My favorite French fry recipe so far! Very crispy and a tasty, satisfying side. I substituted paprika for cayenne, but this recipe is supreme
I like seasoned fries because my Mom. made some a few days ago
Perfect fries. I fried them in olive oil, my son loves them.

I don't think I'll ever make french fries any other way ever again! These were fabulous! 

Not to take away anything from the recipe, I believe it is phenomenal just as is, but here in the South, we like our food heavily seasoned and every home has a can of Tony's Creole Seasoning at the table. So, based on personal preference only, I will probably add an additional tsp of Tony's and seasoned salt to the batter next time. I also used 1 cup of water in my batter and that worked out just right.
Thank you so much for sharing this recipe!
The fries were crispy and great. Instead of paprika I used lemon pepper, salt, seasoned salt, and garlic salt. And they came out amazing I think I will continue to use the recipe forever.
Great recipe! I used beer instead of water and everyone raved about the fries!
Do not try baking these. I baked them and they were inedible. They may be good fried but I tried the baking method listed in the reviews. BIG mistake

I used an outdoor propane deep fryer with a big deep pot. I used the method from another review - mixed the batter in a large tuperware container, then put in the uncooked fries. Then just shook it all of to coat the fries. I also dropped in clumps of fries then mixed them around after about 10 seconds. 
The only thing I'd do different is use a big pan or tray with paper towels. I used a bowel and the bottom fries ended up a bit greasy.
I doubled the seasonings and I used beer instead of water. Very light and. Tasty
Will make again. Delicious
Ordinary fries got boring but this made fries delicious again.
These are great !I followed the recipe exactly but I used an electric skillet set to 350. The whole family liked them, will definitely make again.

Indeed a different way of making chips. The garlic powder and cumin adds an extra twist. I used beer instead of water and very little salt. Will DEFINITELY make them again for a snack.
Used sweet chilli sauce for a dip instead of tomato sauce.

as per another reviewer--I used a deep fryer, added beer (lager) instead of water. For those wondering about dipping each fry separately...thin your batter just slightly @1 Tbsp & put the batter in a medium-sized plastic container with a tight-fitting, well-sealing lid. Add your cut potatoes, seal it up, & SHAKE for @1-2 minutes to coat all the fries. This will evenly coat all the fries w/batter & save time in dipping them separately. When adding the fries to the hot oil... add them using tongs instead of your fingers... and in SMALL-MEDIUM batches. I took the tongs "full bunches" & dropped them into the oil, let the batter set up ever so slightly, then separated them by shaking the bunches until they came apart @1 minute into frying. I'm also impatient & while they didn't come out perfectly "solo" fries...the bunches were crisp.! *USED my deep fryer 375*F. for @ 9 minutes... a nice golden color. Also I ALWAYS use... onion powder & garlic powder... NEVER onion or garlic salt.

Previous Next

i made them i love my french fries and anything soggy you can forget it surprise these really stayed crispy and im not much on mixing things i like quick and easy but well worth it will defiantely make these again Thank you
Best fries ever. Family loves these so cheap. You can use your own seasonings cajun is best. Three grown men to feed 5 stars.

I was SO optimistic for these...

I peeled the potatoes, kept in water while my oil warmed and my coating was completed. I dipped my fries in the batter and set on the pan...
Batter cooked but fries remained raw. In total took almost an hour to be done

While mixing the seasonings, I thought the recipe looked way too salty, so I reduced the salt by 1/2. Big mistake I guess, because they really didn't have any salty flavor at all. The batter itself needed a LOT more water than the 1/2 cup the recipe called for. Still, they were very good and my kids LOVED them. Stayed crispy even the next day :) Tip: Fry longer than you think to get the crispiness. My first batch looked golden, I took them out and put them on a paper towel lined plate, and within minutes they were soggy. My second batch I fried much longer, they were a really dark golden brown color, and this time they remained crispy!!
Will definitely make again. I admit it took a bit more time to stand over stove and fry compared to the frozen bagged fries but 100% better and kids couldn't eat enough! Thank you for recipe.

I selected this recipe because they looked good to me , they turned out exactly how they came out in the picture with a few minor changes . My tip to y'all is today has everything you do with the batter , one change I did was I added more flour because the batter seemed to watery , a tip I used is to use more flour rather then more water .
Amazing

Surprisingly delicious and better than any other method I've used for homemade fries (which isn't often).

I'm from & live in Charleston, SC, so if you know much about this place, you know that we have some fantastic food here. (Charleston is the #1 tourist destination in America and our wonderful food is one of the reasons.) 

That said, the contributor of this recipe is definitely on the right track. As with any recipe, it needed tweaking according to our (or anyone's) personal tastes. We don't generally use recipes. I found this recipe when I was just looking to refresh my memory for some possible tips to make homemade fries better. (And to use the potatoes on-hand to keep from wasting them.) 

The picture I attached was taken this morning--the day after making them and refrigerating the leftovers. They reheat very well for french fries in the oven or a toaster oven. I wouldn't recommend reheating in the microwave because they won't regain the crunchiness that way.

I have a good bit of leftovers. Of course they won't be as crunchy, but they're so tasty that we'll probably chop them up a bit and cover with cheese, bacon, onion, butter, sour cream, gravy, or whatever else for a great version of a loaded baked potato with a twist! 

I didn't measure anything but here are a few of my "tweaks" that I either did or will do next time, having learned from this experience. And there will definitely be a next time on these. 

1. I don't use a lot of salt and I don't ca
I only used half a cup of flour and just enough water to make a thin paste. Fried up awesome and the flavor didn't even require catchup! Will definitely be making these instead of store-bought
